chapter.title: Module
chapter.para: The module enables you, on behalf of your company, to arrange FX options.
For basic features common to all modules, such as basic terminology and the use of lists and forms, see chapter Introduction. For descriptions of functions, see chapter Functions.
This chapter gives detailed descriptions of the input forms used by this module, and describes any features specific to this module.

section.title: FX Options
section.para: This section contains brief descriptions of the types of FX Options models supported by . Unless otherwise stated, all options are European style.

section.title: Digital
section.para: For a call, if on expiration the FX is greater than the strike, the payoff is the notional. If the FX on expiration is less than the strike on expiration, the payoff is zero. For a put, if on expiration the FX is less than the strike, the payoff is the notional. If the FX on expiration is greater than the strike on expiration, the payoff is zero.

section.title: Single Barrier
section.para: Up-and-in calls and puts; Down-and-in calls and puts; Up-and-out calls and puts; Down-and-out calls and puts.

An up-and-in call comes with a barrier set above the current spot FX (the upper barrier). The option becomes a vanilla call when the underlying FX crosses the barrier. If the barrier is never crossed during the life of the option, it expires with a payoff of zero. An up-and-out call comes with a barrier set above the current spot FX (the upper barrier). The option becomes worthless (out) if the barrier is crossed during the life of the option. Otherwise, it expires giving payoff identical to a vanilla call. Others are similar.

section.title: Double Barrier
section.para: Knock-in calls and puts; Knock-out calls and puts.

A double barrier option comes with two barriers. One is above the current spot (upper barrier) and the other below the current spot (lower barrier). A knock-in option becomes a vanilla option when the relevant FX crosses one of the barriers. If the barrier is never crossed during the life of the option, it expires with a payoff of zero. A knock-out call option becomes worthless (out) if either barrier is crossed during the life of the option. Otherwise, it expires giving a payoff identical to a vanilla option. The following field displays the number of days between the As of date and the expiration date.

The delivery date. In theory, when a vanilla option is exercised, a long position of the spot trade is created. To realize the profit, a short position is entered in such a way that on the delivery date (usually the spot day from the date of exercise), the profit is realized in the money currency. The pricing model always takes into account the effect of this delay in profit realization, and performs appropriate discounting (using money currency zero rates).
Tip:In the Delivery date field, you can enter a generic date, used to calculate the deliverydate as follows: O/N = Over Night, 1D = 1 day, 2W = 2 weeks, 3M = 3 months, etc.

This is the settlement amount expressed as a percentage of the Main Currency notional on the spot day from the As Of Date. This percentage appears in the Premium settle % field, following the Premium settle option.

Use this option to enter the premium as a currency amount or percentage. The premium information initially derived is consistent in terms of amount, currency, and settlement date. You can change any or all of these values, in which case you must ensure the consistency of the data. For example, changing the currency from the Main Currency (left leg of the deal) to the Money Currency (right leg of the deal) will automatically change the Premium settle option setting, but will not automatically convert the amount.
